acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: The only test results found on this substance were that the minimum lethal dose for mice is 2000 mg (= 370 ppm)/m3/10m (RTECS, 2004, original literature: National Defense Research Committee, 1942). Given that the vapour pressure of this substance is 100 mmHg (= 13.3 kPa), the saturated concentration is estimated to be 130000 ppm, and the test was presumably conducted in a way of vapour exposure. The minimum lethal dose is converted in unit to 0.4 mg/L/4h, which does not decisively fall under any of the category from Category 1 through the "Not classified" category. As such, the substance was classified into the "Classification not possible" category.

carcinogenicity.rationale: According to IARC Suppl. 7 (1987), ACGIH-TLV (2008), and MAK/BAT (2007), arsenic and its inorganic compounds are categorized as human carcinogens. Thus, the substance was classified into Category 1A.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: No data available. The DFG in Germany has classified arsenic and its inorganic compounds into Category 3A for germ cell mutagenicity (which is equivalent to Category 1B to 2 in the GHS classification) (MAK/BAT, 2007).

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: No test results on this substance were found, but according to description for arsenic and arsenic compounds documented in EHC 224 (2001) which is a List 1 information source, these substances are suggested to affect human reproduction and have teratogenic effects at doses that are toxic to maternal animals. Thus, the substance was classified into Category 2. As additional background information, the Catalog of teratogenic agents (2004), which is equivalent to List 1 sources, supports the conclusion that inorganic arsenic is not teratogenic to humans.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Since inorganic arsenic compounds are reported to irritate human eyes (HSG 70, 1992; PIM 042, 1996), this substance was classified into Category 2. In addition, fluoride is documented to be an eye irritant as well (ACGIH-TLV, 2008; ACGIH, 2001).

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Inorganic arsenic compounds are reported to cause irritation (DFGOT vol. 21, 2005). However, since no further information is available, classification is not possible.

skin_sensitizer.rationale: No test results are available on this substance. Although inorganic arsenic compounds may cause skin sensitization in humans, this is not a definitive conclusion (ATSDR, 2007; HSG, 1992). According to EHC 224 (2001), dermal sensitization to inorganic arsenic appears to be a rare occurrence in humans. Overall, due to insufficient study results available, the substance was classified into the "classification not possible" category.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: It reacts with water to produce hydrogen fluoride gas (the manual for handling poisonous and hazardous substances (Jiji Press, latest version, 2001)), which is not combustible.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification: Category 1 (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, kidney, liver, blood system, respiratory system, skin, bone)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, kidney, liver, blood system, respiratory system, skin, bone)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: No test results on repeated exposure to this substance were found. According to EHC 224 (2001) on arsenic and its inorganic compounds in relation to humans, gastrointestinal tract disorder; nervous disorder; effects on the blood system; and abnormalities in cardiovascular system, kidney, and liver were observed. Thus, target organs for these substances are the gastrointestinal tract, heart, brain, and kidney. In addition, the skin, bone marrow and peripheral nervous system are also affected by these substances. Also, according to ACGIH (2001), the upper respiratory tract and lung are also affected. Furthermore, fluoride is reported to irritate the respiratory tract and affect bones (fluorosis) (ACGIH-TLV, 2008; ACGIH, 2001). Based on these reports, this substance was classified into Category 1 (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, kidney, liver, blood system, respiratory system, skin, and bone).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification: Category 1 (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, blood system, respiratory system, skin, kidney, liver)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, blood system, respiratory system, skin, kidney, liver)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: No test results were found on single exposure to this substance other than lethal effects. In humans, the following acute toxic effects by arsenic compounds are documented: symptoms of the gastrointestinal tract, cardiovascular system, nerves, and blood system; conjunctivitis and dermatitis as well as irritation to the nasal mucosa, pharynx, and trachea; frequent urination or anuria due to a blockage of renal tubules with clots of hemoglobin (IARC 23 (1980)); depression of bone marrow functions; and hepatomegaly (EHC 224 (2001)). In accordance with these reports, the digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, blood system, respiratory system, skin, kidney, and liver were considered to be target organs of these compounds, and this substance was classified into Category 1 (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, blood system, respiratory system, skin, kidney, and liver). In addition, fluoride is also reported to irritate the respiratory tract (ACGIH-TLV, 2008; ACGIH, 2001).
